content.description: The route goes up a right trending ramp, straight over a bulge and then generally up and a bit left to the anchor.  The climbing is fun but the lack of protection will limit the ascents at the grade (we top roped the natural line and perhaps it is a little harder than 5.9--we climbed a more protected variation).  We climbed it with double nines and one can go further up the ramp and cut back left and up to the chain anchor.
content.protection: The pro isn't very good at the crux, the bulge above the ramp. In fact, it would be nice if the route could have one or two bolts on this section so that one wouldn't deck on the ramp. Perhaps one can identify the FA party. Although we didn't climb this section of rock, one should be able to climb the bottom of Catwoman and then continue up and right on gear to the anchor. This would provide a safer alternative to climb the natural line. Bolts and top-anchors updated by CASA in 2017.
content.location: The route is located about 30 feet to the right of Batline.  It starts on a right trending ramp.

content.description:
Pitch 1: (If this is a pitch - my partner and I did not rope up for this) Easy scramble up a blocky corner to a big ledge. Gear anchor.  

  Pitch 2: Hand crack to a roof. Go left at the roof then up and right to a seam in the face past 2 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.   

  Descent: 1 double-rope rappel.
content.location: Located on the far left side of Batline Dome.

content.description: Start at Batline but step out right and clip a bolt.  Continue up and right on pockets and edges (the crux) to a rail.  Clip the second bolt, trend right and then step left onto a left-leaning ramp.  Continue left up the ramp to the top of a small pillar.  Climb generally above the pillar to a bolt anchor.
content.protection: Mixed route (two bolts) so take wires, small tri-cams, small cams and a dozen 24" slings.  The anchor needs chains (about 5 links) to clip to the screw links.
content.location: The route starts in the same location as Batline but trends right and up.  The rap from the anchors will work with a 50m rope.

content.description: This route is generally shady, so it is probably best done in warmer weather.From the end of the road below Batline Dome, walk down the trail into the canyon as though you were going to the Owl Rock or Zappa area. When you reach the bottom of the drainage, go about 50 feet up-canyon. On the left side of the drainage (basically across from the trail that leads up out of the canyon to the Owl Rock) is a faint path that leads about 100 feet up to the shady, back side of Batline Dome. The faint path hits the cliff at a corner (the line of Caped Crusader). P1: Stem up the corner (thin gear) to a stance, then climb past four bolts to an anchor (5.10a/b, 30m).P2: Climb up to a bolt, then go up past numerous chickenheads to a ledge. Above the ledge is an oak tree with slings and a rap ring (5.4, 30m).Rappel the route with a single 60m or longer rope. Make sure to tie knots in the end of the rope, as the first rappel from the tree is exactly 30m!
content.protection: Carry gear to a gold Camalot, including small C3 or similar cams. Rappel the route with a single 60m or longer rope (make sure to tie knots in the end of the rope!).
content.location: From the end of the road below Batline Dome, walk down the trail into the canyon as though you were going to the Owl Rock or Zappa area. When you reach the bottom of the drainage, go about 50 feet up-canyon. On the left side of the drainage (basically across from the trail that leads up out of the canyon to the Owl Rock) is a faint path that leads about 100 feet up to the shady, back side of Batline Dome. The faint path hits the cliff at a corner (the line of Caped Crusader).

content.description: From the base of the rightmost route on the south face of Batline Dome, scramble up and right about 100 feet to a notch on the right crest of the dome. Just over the crest of the notch is a pointed boulder and a view into the canyon behind Batline Dome. Rope up in the notch just above the pointed boulder.Easily traverse up and right about 10 feet on a ramp to gain a vertical crack. Climb the crack past a bulge (crux, red and gold Camalots nearby). Continue up the easy crack to an old anchor that has two widely spaced bolts with Leeper hangers.
content.protection: Finger and hand-sized cams and old two bolt anchor.
content.location: From the base of the rightmost route on the south face of Batline Dome, scramble up and right about 100 feet to a notch on the right crest of the dome. Just over the crest of the notch is a pointed boulder and a view into the canyon behind Batline Dome. Rope up in the notch just above the pointed boulder.

content.description: Step up onto a ledge and then climb a vertical seam and corners to the terrace.  The top of the route is 10 feet left of a small tree on the terrace.
content.protection: Knifeblade pitons, wires, TCUs, and small to medium cams.  Gear anchor, move to the right and rap off bolt anchors.
content.location: Start 30 feet up and left of the Bat Man crack and just right and in front of a large boulder on a slab.

content.description: I found the crux to be near the top; a few meters before exiting the crack.  There are good placements all the way up, but you have to look for them!  I really liked this climb, but I found it harder than a standard 5.9 (as others have suggested).  Lots of stemming involved.
content.protection: Standard rack up to a #4 cam.
content.location: Obvious crack just left of Batline.  Hangers (and I think I remember chains) at the top (up and left) enable you to rap off this route.

climbs.name: Batline
climbs.fa: Eric Fazio-Rhicard, Chris Henze, Cyrena Goodrich & Bob Kerry (1989)

content.description: Climb up to the top of a left leaning ramp. Clip a bolt on the face on the right then climb the face up to a 2 bolt chain anchor at ~70' or continue up to a ledge with a 2 bolt anchor. Single rope rap from first set of anchors or double rope rap from ledge.
content.protection:
Singles with nuts.

 Bolts and top-anchors updated by CASA in 2017.
content.location: Begin a the second ramp left of the parking area, up left from a tree.

content.description: Climb the steep face just right of the Batman crack. There are a few flakes and cracks that provide some protection. At the top, you'll need to move left or right to reach an anchor.This climb can be TR'd from the Batman anchor with appropriate directional pieces.The Batarang was the bat-shaped boomerang used by Batman.
content.protection: Small to medium sized gear needed.
content.location: Start below the steep face that is just right of the Batman crack.

content.description: A system of intermittent edges cracks and seams lies just left of the unknown 5.9+ crack and corner listed on this site. Smaller and less secure holds and smaller and less frequent gear lead to the finish at the anchors as the routs converge. The crux was in the lower 1/3rd.
content.protection: A few small nuts and cams, a little heads-up. There are chain anchor up top shared with the 5.9+ cracks to the right.
content.location: Toward the left edge of the South face of batline dome, about 2 meters left of a more distinct crack and corner system.

content.description: From the end of the road below Batline Dome, walk down the trail into the canyon as though you were going to the Owl Rock or Zappa area. When you reach the bottom of the drainage, go about 50 feet up-canyon. On the left side of the drainage (basically across from the trail that leads up out of the canyon to the Owl Rock) is a faint path that leads about 100 feet up to the shady, back side of Batline Dome. The faint path hits the cliff at a corner (the line of Caped Crusader). This route starts about 25 feet to the left (toward the road) from the corner at a black waterstreak in a right-facing corner.Climb the black waterstreak and right-facing corner to a tree. You could continue up through some brush to connect with Batty, making this an easy but not very esthetic two pitch route.
content.protection: Carry gear to a gold Camalot.
content.location: From the end of the road below Batline Dome, walk down the trail into the canyon as though you were going to the Owl Rock or Zappa area. When you reach the bottom of the drainage, go about 50 feet up-canyon. On the left side of the drainage (basically across from the trail that leads up out of the canyon to the Owl Rock) is a faint path that leads about 100 feet up to the shady, back side of Batline Dome. The faint path hits the cliff at a corner (the line of Caped Crusader). This route starts about 25 feet to the left (toward the road) from the corner at a black waterstreak in a right-facing corner.

climbs.name: Bat Girl
climbs.fa: Donette Swain and Todd Swain November 2000

content.description: Climb up to the top of the ramp passing two bolts (crux) and straight up the pitted fact to the anchor on the terrace (the second and higher Batline anchor).  Otherwise, just climb over to the chain anchor above the crack (Bat Man).
content.protection: Mixed route with two bolts. Take a bit larger rack because the trad gear is a little tricky. Wires, tri-cams, small to medium cams and many 24" slings.  Bolts and top-anchors updated by CASA in 2017.
content.location: Start 15 feet up and left of Batline at the left -hand of two left leaning ramps.

content.description: Located in the East Stronghold. 200-foot-high, south-facing dome on the right side of a canyon.  Stronghold approaches don't get much easier than this one.  Several good 1-2 pitch routes.
